unnormalised: First off, what's considered "normal"? Honestly, it varies! But if you're experiencing persistent heartburn, bloating after every meal (even just 1 roti!), or changes in bowel habits (like going from regular to constipated for >2 weeks), it's worth paying attention. Don't just pop a Digene and hope for the best every time.
normalised: First off, what is considered "normal"? Honestly, it varies! But if you are experiencing persistent heartburn, bloating after every meal (even just one roti!), or changes in bowel habits (like going from regular to constipated for greater than two weeks), it is worth paying attention. Do not just pop a Digene and hope for the best every time.

unnormalised: Common culprits? Stress, diet (hello, spicy biryani!), and sometimes, it’s just your genes. But often I see patients who self-diagnose based on Dr. Google. A little knowledge is a dangerous thing. For instance, many assume IBS (Irritable Bowel Syndrome) based on occasional discomfort.

A little knowledge is a dangerous thing. For instance, many assume I-B-S (Irritable Bowel Syndrome) based on occasional discomfort.

unnormalised: Let's talk about common conditions. Acid reflux is a big one. Avoiding late-night meals and cutting down on chai (sorry!) can help. Next up: gallstones. Symptoms might include sudden, intense pain in your upper right abdomen after eating fatty foods. Could need surgery if it's really bad. The average cost of laparoscopic cholecystectomy is around Rs. 60000 at a private hospital.

unnormalised: Then there's H. pylori, a bacterial infection that can cause ulcers. Easily treatable with antibiotics, but left unchecked, it can lead to bigger problems. A urea breath test at SRL Diagnostics costs approx Rs. 1500. Early detection is key.

unnormalised: Now, a quick word about diagnostics. An endoscopy might sound scary (a tube going down your throat!), but it's a powerful tool. It allows us to visualise your esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Colonoscopies are similar, but for the large intestine. Most Gastroenterologists recommend one every 5 years after the age of 50.

unnormalised: Don't ignore warning signs like blood in your stool, unexplained weight loss (>5 kgs in 6 months), or persistent vomiting. These could be symptoms of something more serious, like colorectal cancer. These symptoms can get worse over time, so it is always best to get things checked sooner rather than later.
